node.contents: @idk: Then you are not going to be able to build your list with that data. The `List` used by `ArrayAdapter` has to be the list of **rows**. According to you, it is not the list of rows. Otherwise, `items.get(1)` would always be returning the first row.

node.contents: @idk: Then your statement where "is supposed to be like that" is incorrect, and your comment on Vickyexpert's answer is incorrect. As I said in my answer, "you can then dump your own `items` data member and adjust `getView()` accordingly". Change `items.get(1).get(position)` to `getItem(position).get(1)` (which is equivalent to what Vickyexpert suggested).

astNode.text: @idk: Then your statement where "is supposed to be like that" is incorrect, and your comment on Vickyexpert's answer is incorrect. As I said in my answer, "you can then dump your own `items` data member and adjust `getView()` accordingly". Change `items.get(1).get(position)` to `getItem(position).get(1)` (which is equivalent to what Vickyexpert suggested).

node.contents:
@idk: "How can I solve this then?" -- replace `List
<list<string>
 >` with `List
 <somemodelclassthatyouwritethatwillhelpyoustopgettingconfusedbynestedlists>
  `. Populate your instances of `SomeModelClassThatYouWriteThatWillHelpYouStopGettingConfusedByNestedLists` from the requisite strings. Make your `ArrayAdapter` then be an `ArrayAdapter
  <somemodelclassthatyouwritethatwillhelpyoustopgettingconfusedbynestedlists>
   `, and adjust `getView()` accordingly.
  </somemodelclassthatyouwritethatwillhelpyoustopgettingconfusedbynestedlists>
 </somemodelclassthatyouwritethatwillhelpyoustopgettingconfusedbynestedlists>
</list<string>

 </somemodelclassthatyouwritethatwillhelpyoustopgettingconfusedbynestedlists>
</list<string>

node.contents: @idk: "And what list of rows?" -- a `ListView` is a list of rows. Your `ListAdapter` also needs to think in terms of rows. In particular, an `ArrayAdapter` needs to have the "array" (e.g., `List`) be a list of model data, where each element in the list *directly* maps to a row in the `ListView`. You are also welcome to abandon `ArrayAdapter` and create your own `BaseAdapter` subclass that deals with your current data structure, if you so choose.

astNode.text: @idk: "And what list of rows?" -- a `ListView` is a list of rows. Your `ListAdapter` also needs to think in terms of rows. In particular, an `ArrayAdapter` needs to have the "array" (e.g., `List`) be a list of model data, where each element in the list *directly* maps to a row in the `ListView`. You are also welcome to abandon `ArrayAdapter` and create your own `BaseAdapter` subclass that deals with your current data structure, if you so choose.

node.contents: What is happening is that ArrayAdapter knows nothing of your List<String>, and so therefore it will return getCount() of 0.

astNode.text: What is happening is that ArrayAdapter knows nothing of your List<String>, and so therefore it will return getCount() of 0.

node.contents: The 0 in the super() call here is safe because you are not chaining to the superclass, electing to handle everything in getView() yourself.

astNode.text: The 0 in the super() call here is safe because you are not chaining to the superclass, electing to handle everything in getView() yourself.

node.contents: However, that points out issues in your getView() implementation:

astNode.text: However, that points out issues in your getView() implementation:

node.contents:
• Please recycle your rows, by using convertView if it is not null

  • Consider using getActivity().getLayoutInflater() instead of always creating a new one, in case the activity either caches a LayoutInflater or supplies you with a specialized one

  • " "+items.get(1).get(position) is probably not a good idea, compared to designing your row layout such that this TextView is positioned where you want it to be

  • Given how many widgets are in your row, please consider using the ViewHolder pattern to cache those findViewById() calls

astNode.text:
• Please recycle your rows, by using convertView if it is not null

  • Consider using getActivity().getLayoutInflater() instead of always creating a new one, in case the activity either caches a LayoutInflater or supplies you with a specialized one

  • " "+items.get(1).get(position) is probably not a good idea, compared to designing your row layout such that this TextView is positioned where you want it to be

  • Given how many widgets are in your row, please consider using the ViewHolder pattern to cache those findViewById() calls
